lg.l: O Navis referent in Mare
Paraphrased & inscribed to Ireland
Novemr 17th 1724
Poor floating Isle tosst on ill Fortunes Waves
Ordain'd by fate to be yẹ Land of Slaves
Shall moveing Delos, now deep rooted Stand
Thou fixt of old, be now yẹ moveing Land?
Alow me one old Simile to Steal
Betwixt a Ship at Sea, & Common weal
Lett me Suppose thee for A Ship a while
And thus address thee, in a Saylor's Style
Unhappy Ship, thou art return'd in vain,
New waves shall drive thee to yẹ deep again
Look to thy Self, & be no more ye: Sport
Of giddy winds, but make Some friendly Port,
Lost are thy oars, which us'd thy Course to guide
Like faithfull Councellors on either Side
Thy mast, which like Some aged Patriot stood
The Single Pillar for his Country's good.
To Lead thee as a Staff directs yẹ blind
Behold itt Cracks by yon rough Eastern wind
Your Cables Burst, and you must quickly feel
The waves imperious entring at Your Keel,
So, Commonwealths receive a foreign Yoke,
When the Strong Cords of union once are broke
Torn by A Sudden Tempest is thy Saile
Expanded to invite a milder Gale,
So, when some writer in A publick Cause
His pen to Save a sinking nation, draws,
While all is calm, his arguments prevail
The people's voice, fanning his paper Sail,
Till power discharging all her Stormy bags
Flutters ye feeble Pamphlett into rags
The nation scar'd yẹ author doom'd to Death
Who fondly putt his trust in pop'lar breath
A larger Sacrifice in vain you vow
There's nott a pow'r above will help you now
A Nation thus who oft Heaven's Call Neglects
In vain from Injur'd Heaven Releif expects
Twill not avail, when thy Strong Sides are broke
That thy Descent is from ye. brittish Oake
Or when Yṛ name & Family you boast
From Fleets triumphant o'er yẹ Gallick Coast,
So, when Hibernia made her Claim like thine
Her Sons descended from yẹ Brittish Line
Her Martial Sons whose valour still remaines
On French Records for twenty long Campaines
Led Captive to A prison from a Throne
Sav'd Europes Liberty, & lost her own
In Ships decay'd no Mariner confides
Lur'd by yẹ gilded Sterns, & painted Sides
So Att a Ball, unthinking fools delight
In the gay Trappings of a birthday night
They on the rich Brocades & Sattins rav'd
Nor ever thought their Country was enslav'd
Dear Vesell, Still be to thy Steerige Just
Nor Change thy Course wtḥ ev'ry gust
Like Supple Patriots of the modern Sort
Who turn by every gale yṭ blows from Court
Weary and Sea Sick, when in thee Confined
Now for thy Safety, Cares distract my minde
As those who long have Stood yẹ Storms of State
Retire, & Still bemoan their Country's fate
But chiefly when you hear ye Surges roar
Avoid yẹ Rocks on Brittains angry Shore:
They lye alas, to easy to be found
For thee alone, they lye yẹ Island round.
